title: 113_hr4565
content: The "Startup Capital Modernization Act of 2014" increases small issues exemptive authority under the Securities Act of 1933 to $10,000,000 and preempts state laws. The amendment to the Securities Act of 1933 clarifies State enforcement authority regarding registration requirements and does not limit State actions against issuers using exemptions. It also clarifies State jurisdiction over unlawful conduct by intermediaries, issuers, and custodians. The amendment to the Securities Act of 1933 expands State enforcement authority to include unlawful conduct by issuers or custodians in transactions described under section 3(b). The Securities Act of 1933 amendment expands State enforcement authority to include unlawful conduct by issuers or custodians in transactions described under section 3(b), excluding from shareholder cap. The Securities Act of 1933 amendment allows for an exclusion for securities issued under Regulation A, exempting them from certain provisions if the issuer meets specific requirements. The Securities and Exchange Commission is required to issue a rule within 180 days to implement this amendment. The exclusion under section 12(g)(7) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 applies to securities issued before, on, or after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. EXEMPTED TRANSACTIONS. Section 4 of the Securities Act of 1933 is amended to include transactions meeting the requirements of subsection (d), where each purchaser is an accredited investor and reasonable steps are taken to verify their status. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to include an exemption for transactions where each purchaser is an accredited investor and verification steps are taken. This exemption is not available for transactions involving certain entities like issuers, underwriters, or dealers. Securities sold under this exemption are not considered part of a public offering. This exemption is not applicable to transactions involving certain entities like issuers, underwriters, or dealers. Securities sold under this exemption are not considered part of a public offering.
